author: VICKY ROACH
title: People Places Things star Jemaine Clement on fatherhood and big hairy giants | DailyTelegraph
text:
JEMAINE Clement has snaffled the role of “fun” parent in his own, Wellington-based family-of- three. No surprises there.
But the 41-year-old comedian, who plays a single dad in his latest film, People Places Things, believes his domestic situation is probably replicated right across the animal world.
“I would say that’s even true of lions — the male lion will play with the cubs while the female goes out and hunts,” he says.

Tree change ... The relationship between Clement and his on-screen twin daughters hits a temporary snag. Picture: Madman Films. “There are things my son likes to do only with me — like acting out big battles,’’ Clement says.
“I think it’s more fun because I am the bigger opponent, physically. It feels like he is destroying an ogre four times his size.”
Such observations might explain six-year-old Sophocles’ enthusiasm for his father’s most recent role — as a big hairy giant in Steven Spielberg’s upcoming adaptation of the Roald Dahl novel BFG.
“He loved coming to the (oversized Vancouver) set. He would help me with my lines and give me little directions: ‘not that voice, the other voice,” Clement says.
No funny voices were called for when it came to People Places Things, which casts Clement in his first, serious leading man role — as a father-of- two struggling to rebuild his life following the breakdown of his relationship.
The teacher and graphic artist Clement plays in James C. Strouse’s film (based on the writer/director’s own life) is closer to the man he is in real life than any of his other characters.
“Villains are much bigger kind of characters and they take more energy,’’ Clement says.
Awkward pause ... Clement with co-star Regina Hall. Picture: Madman Films. “In this one, I can speak in my own voice. I didn’t have to try and be cool or scary or anything like that.”
Clement even got to keep his own Kiwi accent.
“Before I went over to the US, I trained with a dialect coach. But when the director heard it, he said it wasn’t important for me to have (a New York) accent.
“He might have thought it was terrible,” the actor jokes.
“But I know he wanted the character to be from somewhere else and an accent was a good way of establishing that.”
Unlike his character, Clement says he’s never even considered teaching as a way to earn a living
“The idea terrifies me.”
He is, however, quite comfortable with his character’s social awkwardness.
“It’s much truer to life.
“I would love to see an action movie whether the superhero or spy doesn’t have a ready quip, where they think of what they would have liked to have said later.”
While humour is Clement’s speciality, he appreciates why comedies fail to pack as much punch at the box office as, say, a Marvel Comics fantasy.
Quite a team ... Clement with Flight of the Conchords co-star Bret McKenzie. “People have such different ideas about what’s funny — that’s why a comedy will never be as big as an action movie,’’ he says.
“Something like a Monty Python movie might last longer — people will still be watching it, quoting it (30 years on). But it’s a particular audience. And we can all understand what’s sad or exciting.”
Clement is realistic, too, about the size of the potential audience for an independent comedy such as People Things, described by Los Angeles film critic Kenneth Turan as “an antidote to the swarm of studio behemoth that dominate the summer movie calendar.”
“There are so many big films that are loud and in-your face — and they have their place definitely,’’ says Clement.
“But this is at the opposite end of the scale — with real, live situations.
“I’m not sure if it’s an antidote — it won’t stop the big movies — but it might be a break from them.”
SEE: People Places Things opens today.
Originally published as ‘I didn’t have to try and be cool’
